document.docTitle: Phenolic compounds from the flowers of Rosa hugonis Hemsl. and their neuroprotective effects

paragraph.docTitle:
Phenolic compounds from the flowers of
Rosa hugonis Hemsl.
and their neuroprotective effects

subSection.paragraph:
Guolin Zhang a
, Mingkui Wang
a
, Weicheng Hu
b, * , Fu Li
a, **

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: Natural Products Research Center, Chengdu Institute of Biology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Chengdu, 610041, China

paragraph.emphasis: Medical College, Yangzhou University, Yangzhou, 225001, China

Jiangsu Collaborative Innovation Center of Regional Modern Agriculture
&
Environmental Protection / Jiangsu Key Laboratory for Eco-Agricultural Biotechnology
Around Hongze Lake, Huaiyin Normal University, Huaian, 223300, China

emphasis.docAuthorAffiliation: University of Chinese Academy of Sciences , Beijing , 100049, China

subSection.paragraph: ARTICLE INFO
Phenolics
Neuroprotective activity
ABSTRACT

The fragrant flowers of
Rosa hugonis Hemsl. Contain
abundant valuable rose oil and carotenoids. However, phytochemical investigation of this resource rich in phenolics with neuroprotective activity in vitro has been rarely reported. Purification of the 70% ethanol extracts from the flowers of
R. hugonis
by various chromatographic methods resulted in the isolation and characterization of five undescribed acylated flavonoid glycosides (Hugonisflavonoid A-E) together with forty known phenolics. The chemical structures of the undescribed compounds were elucidated by extensive analysis of their spectroscopic data and chemical methods. All the isolates were found from
R. hugonis
for the first time and evaluated for their neuroprotective effects on 6-OHDA induced injury in PC12 cells. Seventeen compounds displayed remarkable protective effects at concentrations of 10 μM. Hugonisflavonoid E can reduce excessive reactive oxygen species and up-regulate mRNA expression levels of superoxide dismutase 1 and catalase. Additionally, hugonisflavonoid E activated the phosphorylated proteins such as PDK1, Akt and GSk-3β. These findings suggested that
R. hugonis
could be a potential source for neuroprotective agents.

The genus
Rosa
L. ( Rosaceae ) is composed of more than 100 wild species and tens of thousands of modern rose cultivars ( Wan et al., 2018 ). In addition to be famous ornamental plants, rose flowers are rich in essential oil and other bioactive constituents such as ellagitannins, flavonoids and phenolic acids ( Chang et al., 2019 ). Therefore, they are widely used in food, cosmetics and pharmaceutical fields.
Rosa hugonis Hemsl. Is
a perennial shrub widely distributed in many provinces in western and northern China ( Zhou et al., 2008 ). The fresh flowers of
R. hugonis
contain valuable volatile oil which smells sweet and fragrant, while the fruits of this plant rich in nutrients can be eaten and brewed ( Zhao et al., 1994 ; Zhou et al., 2008 ). Also, several carotenoids were reported from the yellow petals of this resource (M¨arki-Fischer and Eugster, 1998 ).

footnote.paragraph: * Corresponding author. ** Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: hu_weicheng@163.com (W. Hu), lifu@cib.ac.cn (F. Li).

subSection.paragraph:
reported. A high performance liquid chromatography/photo-diode array (HPLC-PDA) experiment on the flowers of
R. hugonis
showed that they were abundant of flavonoids and other phenolic substances ( Fig. S1 and Table S2 ), which might be responsible for the neuroactive activity. Thus, the present study focused on the isolation and structural characterization of phenolics from the flowers of the title plant. As a result, five undescribed acylated flavonoid glycosides together with forty known phenolics were obtained from this resource ( Fig. 1 ). Furthermore, the neuroprotective effects of the isolates and the underlying mechanism were deeply explored.

Compound 1 , a yellow amorphous powder, had the molecular formula of C 28 H 24 O 13 based on its HRESIMS at m/z 591.1109 [M +Na] + in positive ion mode. The IR spectrumn of 1 showed characteristic absorption bands for hydroxyl ( 3421 cm 1 ), double bonds ( 1608 cm 1 ) and an O-glycosidic group ( 1079 cm 1 ). The UV spectrum of 1 demonstrated absorption bands at λ max 251 and 368 nm , suggesting that compound 1 was a flavonoid. The 1 H NMR data of 1 ( Table 1 ) presented the proton signals at δ H 8.10 (2H, d, J =8.7 Hz), δ H 7.20 (2H, d, J =8.7 Hz), δ H 6.47 (1H, brs), δ H 6.20 (1H, brs) and δ H 5.07 (1H, d, J =7.1 Hz), which were in good accordance with those of kaempferol-4 ′ -O-β- Dglucopyranoside ( Li et al., 2019 ). The 1 H NMR and 13 C NMR spectra of 1 ( Tables 1 and 2 ) also showed two doublet signals at δ H 7.84 (2H, d, J = 8.6 Hz) and δ H 6.88 (2H, d, J =8.6 Hz) and δ C 165.4, δ C 162.2, δ C 131.5, δ C 120.3 and δ C 115.4, respectively, indicating the presence of a p -hydroxybenzoyl group in 1 ( Chulia et al., 1995 ). Acid hydrolysis of 1 afforded kaempferol, p -hydroxybenzoic acid and glucose, which were compared by co-TLC and HPLC with the authentic samples. Moreover, the glucose moiety was determined to be in β -D-glucose form by measuring its optical rotation and inferring from the large coupling constant (7.2 Hz) of the anomeric proton. The linkages between kaempferol, glucose and p -hydroxybenzoic acid were determined by the key long-range correlations from δ H 5.07 (H-1 of Glc) to δ C 158.2 (C-4 ′ of kaempferol unit), and from δ H 4.59, 4.18 (H-6 of Glc) to δ C 165.4 (C-7 of p -hydroxybenzoyl unit) ( Fig. 2 ). By extensive analysis of the 1 H-NMR, 13 C-NMR, DEPT, 1 H– 1 H COSY) HSQC, and HMBC data, the structure of compound 1 was ulteriorly defined as kaempferol 4 ′ - O -(6 ′′ - O -p -hydroxybenzoyl)- β -D-glucopyranoside ( Fig. 1 ), named hugonisflavonoid A.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 1. Representative structures of phenolics from
R. hugonis
(* Undescribed compounds).
1 H NMR Spectral Data for Compounds 1–5 ( δ in ppm, J in Hz).

tableNote.paragraph: 6 d Recorded in CD OD. m: multiple signal, o:overlapped.

subSection.paragraph: Compound 2 was isolated as a yellow amorphous powder and showed an HRESIMS peak at m/z 607.1059 [M + Na] + , indicating a molecular formula of C 28 H 24 O 14 . The 13 C and 1 H NMR data of 2 ( Tables 1 and 2 ) were similar to those of known compound 6 , except that the galloyl group in 6 was replaced by a p -hydroxybenzoyl in 2 . Acid hydrolysis of 2 gave quercetin, p -hydroxybenzoic acid and glucose, further confirming the difference between compounds 2 and 6 . Detailed analysis of the DEPT, 1 H– 1 H COSY, HSQC, and HMBC spectra definitely supported the structure of compound 2 as quercetin 4 ′ - O -(6 ′′ - O -p - hydroxybenzoyl)- β -D-glucopyranoside and named as hugonisflavonoid B.

The molecular formula of compound 3 was determined as C 30 H 26 O 13 according to the peak at m/z 617.1264 [M +Na] + in HRESIMS. The 13 C and 1 H NMR data of 3 ( Tables 1 and 2 ) was almost identical to those of 1 for the kaempferol and sugar residue. The 1 H NMR signals appearing at δ H 7.51 (1H, d, J =15.8 Hz), δ H 7.48 (2H, d, J =8.5 Hz), δ H 6.70 (2H, d, J =8.5 Hz), and δ H 6.37 (1H, d, J =15.8 Hz) suggested the existence of a trans -p -coumaroyl fragment in 3 rather than a p -hydroxybenzoyl group in 1 ( Bai et al., 2017 ). By extensive 1D and 2D NMR data analysis, along with acid hydrolysis, compound 3 was unambiguously defined as kaempferol 4 ′ - O -(6 ′′ - O - (E)-p -coumaroyl)- β -D-glucopyranoside, named hugonisflavonoid C.

Compound 4 was isolated as a yellow amorphous powder, and the peak at m/z 633.1210 [M + Na] + in HRESIMS suggested its molecular formula as C 30 H 26 O 14 . Comparison of the 1 H and 13 C NMR data ( Tables 1 and 2 ) of 4 to those of 3 could easily conclude that the discrepancies between these two compounds were in accordance with those between compounds 1 and 2 , revealing compound 4 bore a quercetin backbone. In combination with the DEPT, 1 H– 1 H COSY, HSQC, and HMBC data, the structure of 4 was characterized as quercetin 4 ′ - O -(6 ′′ - O - (E)-p -coumaroyl)- β -D-glucopyranoside, named hugonisflavonoid D.

The molecular formula of compound 5 , C 28 H 24 O 15 , was deduced from the peak at m/z 623.1002 [M +Na] + in its HRESIMS. Compounds 5 and 1 shared the same kaempferol 4 ′ - O -β -D-glucopyranoside fragment by comparison of their NMR data ( Tables 1 and 2 ). The 1 H NMR and 13 C NMR spectra of 5 also showed one singlet at δ H 7.14 (2H, s) and δ C 168.2, δ C 146.5, δ C 139.9, δ C 121.3 and δ C 110.3, respectively, indicating the presence of a galloyl group [ Okamura et al., 1993a ,b]. With the aid of 1D and 2D NMR spectra, compound 5 was finally elucidated as kaempferol 4 ′ - O -(6 ′′ - O - galloyl)- β -D-glucopyranoside, named hugonisflavonoid E.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 2. Key HMBC correlations of compound 1–5 .

heading.emphasis: 2.2. Effects of different compounds on 6-OHDA-induced PC12 cell injury

subSection.paragraph: Parkinson’ s disease (PD) is one of the most common neurodegenerative movement disorder, where oxidative stress appears to be an important element in PD. 6-OHDA could induce intracellular ROS overproduction and was often used in drug screening for Parkinson’ s disease models in vitro ( Ju et al., 2010 ; Shi et al., 2011 ; Zhang et al., 2017 ). As shown in Table S1 , compounds 5 , 6 , 13–16 , 18–19 , 32 , 36–38 , 40–41 , 43–45 presented significant activities. Nevertheless, many of these compounds showed remarkable ability to promote cell proliferation. In order to eliminate the effects of cell proliferation, compound 5 , which had a novel chemical structure and exhibited relatively good activity, was selected for further investigation of its inhibitory effect on 6-OHDA-induced toxicity in PC12 cells. As shown in Fig. 3A , the cell viability was increased from 49.83% to 72.91%, 94.78%, 91.76%, 103.08% and 110.67%, respectively. When the concentration of compound 5 was 20 μM or less, there was almost no effect on cell viability ( Fig. 3B ). Therefore, the concentrations used in subsequent studies were 20 μM or lower. As shown in Fig. 3C , the cell numbers were reduced and attached cells were round and shrunken in 6-OHDA-- treated group. Pretreatment with compound 5 restored the changes in cell number and morphology.

heading.emphasis: 2.3. Effects of compound 5 on 6-OHDA-induced ROS generation

subSection.paragraph: Oxidative stress, defined as the overproduction of ROS, could cause alterations in proteins, lipids, DNA, glycogen and disrupt cellular homeostasis ( Anik et al., 2022 ; Jellinger, 2010 ). Previous studies suggested that excessive ROS contributed to dopaminergic neuronal cell loss and pathophysiology of disorders in PD patients ( Weng et al., 2018 ). The antioxidant enzymes, such as SOD and CAT, are the key enzymes in body system to protect against oxidative stress ( Yaribeygi et al., 2019 ). As shown in Fig. 4A , the exposure of PC12 cells to 6-OHDA induced a marked increase of the cell fluorescence intensity in comparison to vehicle group. However, pretreatment with compound 5 induced a significant decrease of ROS levels. As shown in Fig. 4B and C , treatment of PC12 cells with 6-OHDA for 6 h significantly decreased the activities of SOD and CAT. However, pretreatment with compound 5 dramatically minimized the 6-OHDA-induced changes in antioxidant enzyme activities. These results suggested that the neuroprotective effect of compound 5 might be mediated by antioxidant defense mechanism.

heading.emphasis: 2.4. Effects of compouond 5 on the 6-OHDA-induced PI3K/Akt/GSK-3β

subSection.paragraph: PI3K/Akt is an important signaling pathway that controls many cellular processes, including cell division, autophagy, survival, and differentiation ( Jafari et al., 2019 ). Previous investigations have reported that natural products with protective activities against 6-OHDA-induced neurotoxicity may be mediated through the activation of PI3K/Akt/GSK3β signaling pathway, suggesting that the activation of GSK3β should be an important target ( Long et al., 2021 ; Zhang et al., 2019 ). We therefore examined the phosphorylated levels of PDK1, Akt, and G3K-3β. As shown in Fig. 5 , the phosphorylated levels of PDK1, Akt, and G3K-3β were decreased compared with the control group. Compound 5 pretreatment significantly alleviated the declines of these three phosphorylated proteins.

caption.paragraph:

subSection.paragraph:
In summary, detailed phytochemical investigation suggested that
R. hugonis
was abundant in flavonoid glycosides with kaempferol, quercetin and 8-methoxykaempferol as the aglycones ( 1–19 ), which contributted to the main neuroactive activity of this resource. According to the chemcial structures of compounds 1–6 and their neuroactive activity, it could be conluded that the presence of a hydroxyl group at C-3 ′ was unfavorable for neuroactive activity. Compounds 5–6 showed better activity than compounds 1–4 , which might be due to the existence of more hydroxyl groups on the corresponding acylated groups. Compounds 33 , 35 and 38 shared similarities in the chemical structure and exhibited remarkable neuroprotective activity, pointing out the direction for the development of related small molecule synthetic drugs. Although gallic acid analogues ( 41 , 42 , 44 and 45 ) showed excellent neuroactive activity, they were widespread in nature and lacked selectivity in biological activity. Furthermore, it was demonstrated that compound 5 protected against 6-OHDA induced oxidative stress through the upregulation of the PI3K/Akt/GSK3β signaling pathway. The results of the present study indicated that the flowers of
R. hugonis
could serve as an alternative source for neuroprotective agents. Spireoside ( 16 ) showed good neuroactive activity in vitro and had been obtained in gram scale. Thus, a further study is in progress to evaluate the in vivo neuroprotective activity of this compound.

caption.paragraph:

(B–C) PC12 cell were treated with different concentration of compound 5 before exposure to 6-OHDA for 24 h. The relative mRNA expression levels of SOD and CAT were determined by RT-qPCR. The values are presented as the mean ± SD (n = 3). *

subSection.paragraph: Infrared (IR) spectra were gained on a PerkinElmer 1725X-FT spectrometer. Ultraviolet (UV) spectra were measured on a PerkinElmer lambda 35 UV/vis spectrophotometer. Optical rotations were obtained on a PerkinElmer 341 polarimeter. 1D ( 1 H-NMR, 13 C-NMR and DEPT135) and 2D ( 1 H– 1 H COSY, HSQC and HMBC) NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Avance 600 and a Bruker Avance III 400 spectrometer, respectively. High-resolution electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (HRESIMS) spectra were acquired on an LTQ Orbitrap XL mass spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, San Jose, CA, U.S.A. ). Analytical HPLC analysis was carried out on a Nexera LC-20AD with a model SPD-M40 photo diode array detector (Shimadzu, Japan ) and a Neptune C18 column ( 250 mm × 4.60 mm , 5 μm). Preparative and semi-preparative HPLC operations were performed on a CXTH apparatus with a UV3000 detector at 254 nm ( Beijing Innovation Technology Co., Ltd., Beijing , China ) equipped with GLP Prep-HPLC (250 × 50 mm , 10 μm) and GLP Prep-HPLC (250 × 30 mm , 10 μm) columns (Nanomicro Technology Co., Ltd., Suzhou, China ), respectively. Plates used for TLC were purchased from Qingdao Marine Chemical Group Co., Ltd. (Qingdao, China ). Sephadex LH-20 for column chromatography was obtained from GE Healthcare Bio-Sciences AB ( Uppsala , Sweden ). Methanol (HPLC grade), acetonitrile (HPLC grade), 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide (MTT) and 6-hydroxydopamine hydrobromide (6-OHDA) were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich (St. Louis, MO, U.S.A. ). The standard sugar of D-glucose, kaempferol, quercetin, p -hydroxybenzoic acid, ( E )- p -coumaric acid and gallic acid were purchased from Chengdu PhytoElite Bio-technology Company Limited (Chengdu, Sichuan , China ). The fetal bovine serum (FBS) was purchased from Corning (Medford, MA, U.S.A. ). Penicillin streptomycin solution was obtained from Invitrogen-Gibco (Carlsbad, CA, U.S.A. ). Protease and phosphatase inhibitor cocktail tablets were from Roche (Mannheim, Germany ). Phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) tables were bought from Amresco (Solon, OH, U.S.A. ). Goat antirabbit immunoglobulin G (IgG) H&L horseradish peroxidase (HRP) was purchased from abcam (Cambridge, MA, U.S.A. ). Phospho-PDK1, PDK1, phospho-GSK-3β, GSK-3β, phospho-Akt and Akt were maintained from Cell Signaling Technology (Beverly, MA, U.S.A. ). PC12 cells were obtained from the ATCC (Rockville, MD, USA ). All cell culture supplies were bought from Corning (Medford, MA, U.S.A. ). A ROS assay kit (CA1410) purchased from Solarbio Life Sciences ( Shanghai , China ). Bradford reagent, eECL Western Blot kit, lysis buffer, nuclear and cytoplasmic extraction kit were obtained from CoWin Biosciences ( Beijing , China ). The deuterated solvents were bought from CIL Co. (YRTC, China ). All normal organic solvents (petroleum ether, ethyl acetate, dichloromethane, ethanol and methanol) were of the analytical grade and bought from Chengdu Kelong Chemicals Reagent Co. Ltd. (Chengdu, China ). The stock solutions of compounds were prepared in DMSO to 100 mM and the final concentration of DMSO was not in excess of 0.1% at any treatment.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 5. Effects of compound 5 on PI3K/Akt/GSK-3β signaling pathway in 6- OHDA induced PC12 cells. The levels of total or phosphorylated PDK1, Akt and GSK-3β were identified by Western blot. β- Actin was used as a control.

subSection.paragraph:
The flowers of
R. hugonis (Rosaceae)
were collected from Mao County , Aba Tibetan and Qiang Autonomous Prefecture , Sichuan Province , China , in
April 2019
. The plant materials were identified by Professor Weikai Bao , Chengdu Institute of Biology ,
Chinese Academy of Sciences.
A voucher specimen (CIB–H-401) has been deposited in the herbarium of Natural Product Research Center , Chengdu Institute of Biology , Chinese Academy of Sciences
.

Air-dried flowers of
R. hugonis
( 1.9 kg ) were smashed and then extracted with 70% EtOH at room temperature for three times (each time 12 L for 3 days). The combined extract solutions were evaporated under reduced pressure to yield a crude extract ( 706 g ), which was suspended in purified water and extracted with CH 2 Cl 2 and n -BuOH, successively. The dried n -BuOH extract ( 210 g ) was fractionated over a Sephadex LH-20 column ( 460 mm × 80 mm ) with a gradient solvent system of MeOH/H 2 O (10:90, 30:70, 40:60, 50:50, 60:40, 70:30, 80:20, and 90:10) to afford eleven fractions monitored by TLC analysis (Fractions A K). Fraction B was separated over a Toyopearl HW-40 column ( 300 mm × 40 mm ) with MeOH–H 2 O (30:70, v/v) as the eluent to yield three subfractions (subfractions B1–B3). Compounds 27 ( 42.2 mg ; t R , 22.2 min), 28 ( 20.8 mg ; t R , 13.5 min), 29 ( 34.9 mg ; t R , 15.3 min), and 30 ( 26.3 mg ; t R , 18.6 min) were obtained from subfraction B2 by semi-preparative HPLC eluted by the mixed solvent of CH 3 CN–H 2 O (20 mL/ min, 32:68, v/v). Fraction C was subject to preparative HPLC using CH 3 CN–H 2 O with 1% CH 3 COOH (60 mL/min, 25:75, v/v) as the eluent to afford three subfractions (subfractions C1–C3). Subfraction C1 was separated by semi-preparative HPLC eluted with CH 3 CN–H 2 O with 1% CH 3 COOH (20 mL/min, 10:90, v/v) to give 26 ( 40.2 mg ; t R , 30.3 min). Compound 38 ( 31.4 mg ; t R , 16.8 min) was isolated from subfraction C2 by semi-preparative HPLC eluted by CH 3 CN–H 2 O with 1% CH 3 COOH (20 mL/min, 25:75, v/v). Fraction D was repeatly applied to a Sephadex LH-20 column with MeOH–H 2 O (30:70, v/v) as the mobile phase to yield four subfractions (subfractions D1-D4). Compound 21 ( 22.7 mg ) and 39 ( 41.8 mg ) were crystallized from subfraction D1 and D2, respectively. Compounds 33 ( 14.2 mg ; t R , 16.8 min) and 34 ( 19.8 mg ; t R , 18.0 min) were purified from subfraction D3 by semi-preparative HPLC with CH 3 CN–H 2 O (20 mL/min, 40:60, v/v) as the eluent. Subfraction D4 was further separated by semi-preparative HPLC eluted with CH 3 CN–H 2 O containing 1% CH 3 COOH (20 mL/min, 6:94, v/v) as the mobile phase to give 43 ( 18.5 mg ; t R , 16.0 min) and 44 ( 22.2 mg ; t R , 9.9 min). Fraction E was divided into five subfractions (subfractions E1-E5) by repeated preparative HPLC chromatography eluted by CH 3 CN–H 2 O containing 1% CH 3 COOH (60 mL/min, 19:81, v/v). Compound 40 ( 105.1 mg ; t R , 15.3 min) was obtained from subfraction E2 by semi-preparative HPLC using CH 3 CN–H 2 O containing 1% CH 3 COOH (20 mL/min, 11:89, v/v) as the mobile phase. Subfraction E3 was further purified by semi-preparative HPLC with CH 3 CN–H 2 O containing 1% CH 3 COOH (20 mL/min, 15:85, v/v) as the eluent to give 37 ( 22.2 mg ; t R , 17.8 min). Compounds 18 ( 45.6 mg ; t R , 12.2 min) and 19 ( 61.8 mg ; t R , 14.4 min) were obtained from subfraction E4 by semi-preparative HPLC with CH 3 CN–H 2 O containing 1% CH 3 COOH (20 mL/min, 25:75, v/v). Compound 42 ( 1.03 g ) was crystallized from fraction F. The remaining solution was further separated by semi-preparative HPLC eluted with CH 3 CN–H 2 O containing 1% CH 3 COOH (20 mL/min, 10:90, v/v) to afford 32 ( 17.7 mg ; t R , 16.2 min) and 41 ( 18.1 mg ; t R , 13.9 min). Fraction G was first applied on an ODS column ( 300 mm × 40 mm ) eluted with a gradient solvent system of MeOH/H 2 O (20:80 to 100:0, v/ v) to yield five subfractions (subfractions G1-G5). Compounds 10 ( 60.3 mg ; t R , 40.3 min), 11 ( 83.3 mg ; t R , 30.2 min), 12 ( 201.7 mg ; t R , 21.8 min), and 15 ( 159.9 mg ; t R , 16.1 min) were purified from subfraction G2 by preparative HPLC eluted with CH 3 CN–H 2 O containing 1% CH 3 COOH (60 mL/min, 38:62, v/v). Subfraction G4 was repeatly separated by semi-preparative HPLC with CH 3 OH–H 2 O containing 1% CH 3 COOH (20 mL/min, 52:48, v/v) to yield compounds 7 ( 40.9 mg ; t R , 11.2 min), 8 ( 23.8 mg ; t R , 27.7 min), 9 (34.0 mg; t R , 23.0 min), 17 ( 37.3 mg ; t R , 19.4 min), 20 ( 27.1 mg ; t R , 22.1 min), 25 ( 543.9 mg ; t R , 23.4 min), 31 ( 30.6 mg ; t R , 17.6 min), 35 ( 32.5 mg ; t R , 39.7 min), 36 ( 29.1 mg ; t R , 28.4 min), and 45 ( 28.4 mg ; t R , 18.0 min). Further purification of fraction H by preparative HPLC eluted with CH 3 CN–H 2 O containing 1% CH 3 COOH (60 mL/min, 27:73, v/v) gave compounds 13 ( 119.6 mg ; t R , 27.0 min) and 16 ( 2.04 g ; t R , 21.9 min). Fraction I was separated by repeat preparative HPLC eluted with CH 3 CN–H 2 O containing 1% CH 3 COOH (60 mL/min, 43:57, v/v) to yield seven subfractions (subfractions I1–I7). Compounds 22 ( 400.4 mg ; t R , 22.0 min), 23 ( 1.10 g ; t R , 31.6 min), and 24 ( 253.7 mg ; t R , 18.8 min) were isolated from subfraction I1 through preparative HPLC eluted with CH 3 CN–H 2 O containing 1% CH 3 COOH (60 mL/min, 25:75, v/v). Similarly, compounds 6 ( 39.8 mg ; t R , 14.8 min) and 5 (20.0 mg; t R , 16.4 min) were purified by semi-preparative HPLC from subfractions I2 and I3, respectively, with CH 3 CN–H 2 O containing 1% CH 3 COOH (20 mL/min, 33:67, v/v) as the mobile phase. Further separation of subfraction I4 by semi-preparative HPLC using CH 3 CN–H 2 O containing 1% CH 3 COOH (20 mL/min, 36:64, v/v) as the eluent afforded 2 ( 39.2 mg ; t R , 38.8 min) and 4 (28.0 mg; t R , 30.3 min). Subfraction I5 was further separated by semi-preparative HPLC eluted with CH 3 CN–H 2 O containing 1% CH 3 COOH (20 mL/min, 38:62, v/v) yielded 14 (60.0 mg; t R , 29.9 min). Compounds 1 ( 19.4 mg ) and 3 ( 22.7 mg ) were obtained from subfraction I6 by semi-preparative HPLC eluted with CH 3 CN–H 2 O containing 1% CH 3 COOH (20 mL/min, 36:64, v/v).

heading.emphasis: 4.4. Acid hydrolysis and components analysis of compounds 1–5

subSection.paragraph: Briefly, each undescribed compound (1.0 mg) was dissolved in 2 M HCl (1.0 mL) and heated in a water bath for 5 h at 80 ◦ C. The reactants were firstly neutralized with 2 M NaOH and then extracted exhaustively with EtOAc to get the supernatant, which was dried under reduce pressure. The dried substances were analyzed by co-TLC with anthentic kaempferol, quercetin, p -hydroxybenzoic acid, ( E )- p -coumaric acid and gallic acid ( CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH, 4:1). The remaining water layer was concentrated and then subject to TLC with anthentic glucose sample ( CH 2 Cl 2 –MeOH–H 2 O, 2:1, water saturated). The absolute configuration of the glucose residue in compounds 1–5 was determined to be in D-form by measuring their optical rotations ranging from [α] +45.7 ◦ to [α]+ 53.4 ◦ .

Hugonisflavonoid A ( 1 ). Yellow amorphous powder; [α], 58.1 ◦ ( c 0.1, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ), 251 nm (3.63), 367 nm (3.16); IR (KBr) ν max , 3421, 2925, 1608, 1079 cm 1 ; HR-ESI-MS m/z 591.1109 [M +Na] + (calcd. For C 28 H 24 O 13 Na + , 591.1109); and 1 H and 13 C NMR data are shown in Tables 1 and 2

Hugonisflavonoid B ( 2 ). Yellow amorphous powder; [α], 56.2 ◦ ( c 0.1, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 196 nm (4.27), 266 nm (3.67), 312 nm (3.17), 367 nm (3.32); IR (KBr) ν max , 3415, 1609, 1507, 1200, 1072, 779, 617 cm 1 ; HR-ESI-MS m/z 607.1059 [M + Na] + (calcd. For C 28 H 24 O 14 Na + , 607.1058); and 1 H and 13 C NMR data are shown in Tables 1 and 2

Hugonisflavonoid C ( 3 ). Yellow amorphous powder; [α], 61.4 ◦ ( c 0.1, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 254 nm (3.63), 367 nm (3.47); IR (KBr) ν max , 3421, 2925, 1608, 1079, 603 cm 1 ; HR-ESI-MS m/z 617.1264 [M +Na] + (calcd. For C 30 H 26 O 13 Na + , 617.1266); and 1 H and 13 C NMR data are shown in Tables 1 and 2

Hugonisflavonoid D ( 4 ). Yellow amorphous powder; [α], 63.2 ◦ ( c 0.1, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 224 nm (3.54), 245 nm (4.27), 271 nm (3.37), 312 nm (3.29), 368 nm (3.27); IR (KBr) ν max , 3441, 1608, 1073, 829, 602 cm 1 ; HR-ESI-MS m/z 633.1210 [M + Na] + (calcd. For C 30 H 26 O 14 Na + , 633.1215); and 1 H and 13 C NMR data are shown in Tables 1 and 2

Hugonisflavonoid E ( 5 ). Yellow amorphous powder; [α], 59.8 ◦ ( c 0.1, MeOH); UV (MeOH) λ max (log ε ) 198 nm (4.36), 219 nm (4.37), 270 nm (3.25), 368 nm (3.17); IR (KBr) ν max , 3391, 1693, 1653, 1611, 1242, 1073, 830, 602 cm 1 ; HR-ESI-MS m/z 623.1002 [M + Na] + (calcd. For C 28 H 24 O 15 Na + , 623.1007); and 1 H and 13 C NMR data are shown in Tables 1 and 2

PC12 cells were maintained in DMEM supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum, 5% horse serum, 100 U/mL penicillin, and 100 mg /mL streptomycin in a humidified atmosphere of 5% CO 2 . The cytoprotective effect of test samples on 6-OHDA-induced PC12 cells was measured with an MTT-based colorimetric assay ( Luo et al., 2019 ). Briefly, 3 × 10 5 cells/well were pre-treated with different compounds for 30 min before exposure to 6-OHDA (250 μM) for 24 h. The supernatant was removed, 100 μL of MTT solution was added and incubated for 4 h at 37 ◦ C. After that 100 μL of MTT solution was added to every well to solubilize formazan. The absorbance at 550 nm was determined with a microplate reader.

PC12 cells were grown overnight at 3 × 105 cells/well in a 96-well plate. The cells were treated with compound 5 for 10 min before exposure to 6-OHDA for 24 h and photographed under fluorescence microscopy.

heading.emphasis: 4.8. Measurement of ROS with DCFH-DA staining

subSection.paragraph: To evaluate intracellular reactive oxygen species (ROS) production, PC12 cell were treated with different concentration of compound 5 before exposure to 6-OHDA for 24 h. Cells were then stained with DCFH-DA for 1 h at 37 ◦ C. Cells were subsequently fixed and observed under an Olympus IX71 confocal microscope.

Total RNA was extracted from PC12 cell by using TRIzol reagent and reversed transcribed into cDNA using Recert Aid First Strand cDNA synthesis kit (Thermo scientific). Real-time PCR was performed in a 20 μL reaction system containing cDNA, primers, and SYBR (Roche). GAPDH was used an internal control gene. The primers sequences were in this study were listed in Table S3.

All tests were carried out independently in triplicate (n =3). Results in the present study were represented as the mean ± SD (standard deviation). The significance was analyzed between the two groups using Student’ s t -test and p -values less than 5% were considered to be statistically different.

Data will be made available on request.
